title: What are some good historically accurate movies? - Quora

response.answer_text: None of them. Even the “best” movies that are held up as paragons of historical truth that have been altered to improve the drama. Oliver Stone’s “JFK” was pointed out as some kind of historical truth, but he created characters that didn’t really exist to make the story move along, such as Kevin Bacon’s character. “Schindler’s List” plays up the nobility of Oscar Schindler, especially at the end when he makes the long speech about how he could have “saved more”. That never happened. Schindler was truly a slimy self-promoter who slunk off in the night to escape the approaching Russians after the surrender. And “Downfall” the epic movie of Hitler’s last days totally fabricates the episode of Hitler’s brother-in-law’s breakdown, desertion and execution. It even gives him a “noble” end, standing straight to take the bullets coming after him when others reported he died sniveling and cowering. The ridiculous and awful “Pearl Harbor” remake with Ben Affleck has so many flaws and compresses the Pearl Harbor event with the Doolittle Raid to get blockbuster sales as opposed to historical accuracy, in the same way the “Alamo” remake puts words in the mouths of characters that they didn’t say and compresses the Alamo with the defeat of Santa Ana just to create a bookend story, not one that is historical. The ridiculously awful WW2 epic “Battle of the Bulge” with Henry Fonda is just so pathetically inept and yet growing up, my friends and I all believed it was the “truth”. Movies are made to make money, not depict history. History is complex and not always unfolding in a neat and tidy way that makes for a good story that can be told in 90 minutes and make hundreds of millions of dollars. Unfortunately we’ve come to believe that movies can bring history to life. The downside is that years later people tend to believe the movie version, not the truth, and that’s how legends and myths are made.

There is No film ever made in history of cinema, where it got the history right. Filmmakers put some extra things or remove some extra things to sell their movie.
